docs.lead_paragraph: Fearful of too many refugees flooding into the country, Swiss voters overwhelmingly approved tighter rules today for asylum-seekers and trounced a Government proposal for paid maternity leave. Voting as part of Switzerland's direct democracy system, citizens cast more than 70 percent of ballots in favor of the Government measures to cut down on the number of refugees to be given permanent asylum. Already home to some 180,000 Kosovo Albanians, Switzerland has been experiencing an enormous influx of refugees fleeing the Serbian province. Switzerland is expecting as many as 60,000 refugees by the year's end -- giving it the highest number per inhabitant in Europe.

headline.main: Swiss Approve Asylum Limits And Reject Maternity Benefit

docs.abstract: Voters in Switzerland, which has been experiencing enormous influx of refugees from Kosovo, overwhelmingly approve Government proposal to tighten rules for permanent asylum; reject proposal for paid maternity leave (M)
docs.snippet: Fearful of too many refugees flooding into the country, Swiss voters overwhelmingly approved tighter rules today for asylum-seekers and trounced a Government proposal for paid maternity leave.    Voting as part of Switzerland's direct democracy...

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Susan H., age 40, began experiencing excessive menstrual bleeding and almost constant pelvic pain and cramping, her doctor's diagnosis was straightforward and certain: She had multiple uterine fibroids, benign tumors that grow within the smooth muscle of the uterine wall or on the uterine surface. Susan's response was equally sure: ''I did not want a hysterectomy. I hadn't ruled out having children, and even if I never had a child, I did not want to lose my uterus.''

headline.main: Diagnosing Fibroids Is Simple; Deciding What to Do Is Hard

docs.abstract: Tracey Harden article on treating fibroids, benign tumors of uterous; hysterectomy has historically been treatment of choice for fibroids that cause severe symptoms, but many women are chosing alternatives, including surgical removal of individual tumors and procedure that cuts off blood supply to fibroids; photo (special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN Susan H., age 40, began experiencing excessive menstrual bleeding and almost constant pelvic pain and cramping, her doctor's diagnosis was straightforward and certain: She had multiple uterine fibroids, benign tumors that grow within the smooth...

docs.lead_paragraph: ALWAYS enthralled by record-shattering events, Americans were mesmerized by the birth of septuplets in 1997 and octuplets the following year. Each tiny infant's struggle from birth canal to home crib was reported and broadcast in detail, and the nation's heart swelled with empathy for the parents. At the same time, such extraordinary numbers of simultaneous siblings provoked fits of hand-wringing and soul-searching. What has science wrought? The Iowa Seven, the Texas Eight and thousands of smaller sets of multiples are arriving, overwhelmingly through assisted reproductive technologies. And while the number of such births is still small, the incidence has quadrupled since the mid-1980's. Yet there is no illusion about the risks high-order multiples (three or more infants) and their families face.

headline.main: Doctors Are Second-Guessing the 'Miracle' of Multiple Births

docs.abstract: Multiple births of three or more infants, unintended, and perhaps unfortunate, consequence of infertility treatments, have quadrupled since mid-1980's; medical community is divided on whether and how to limit incidence of such high-order multiples, which pose risks to infants and their families; many couples bearing expense of in vitro fertilization are insisting on using multiple embryos to improve odds of success; photo (special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: ALWAYS enthralled by record-shattering events, Americans were mesmerized by the birth of septuplets in 1997 and octuplets the following year. Each tiny infant's struggle from birth canal to home crib was reported and broadcast in detail, and the...

docs.lead_paragraph: As times change in Ireland, so too does the influence of the Roman Catholic Church, once the ineffable, undisputed authority of life here. Ireland still looks and feels like western Europe's most Catholic country -- an estimated 90 percent of its 3.6 million people consider themselves practicing churchgoers, people still cross themselves when they pass a church, most have ashes daubed on their foreheads on Ash Wednesday and flock to churches on Easter. Angelus bells calling the faithful to prayer still ring twice daily on national radio and television.

headline.main: Scandals and New Beliefs Changing Ireland's Church

docs.abstract: Influence of Roman Catholic Church in Ireland is changing; estimated 90 percent of Irish consider themselves Catholic; as country's economy has soared, it has become less formally religious, like rest of Western Europe; series of sex scandals involving Roman Catholic priests and bishops has left church searching for new role, more akin to spiritual adviser than rigid arbiter of social and sexual mores (M)
docs.snippet: As times change in Ireland, so too does the influence of the Roman Catholic Church, once the ineffable, undisputed authority of life here.    Ireland still looks and feels like western Europe's most Catholic country -- an estimated 90 percent of its...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Swiss will decide on Sunday whether to provide new mothers with the kind of salary protections that every other Western European country affords women after they give birth. While such benefits are tenuous in the United States, they are common in Europe. Only Switzerland fails to guarantee a woman's salary following childbirth -- even though it requires by law that women take eight weeks off after having a baby.

headline.main: Swiss Will Decide if Motherhood Warrants Salary Protection

docs.abstract: Swiss voters will decide whether to provide new mothers with salary protections after they give birth; in Western Europe, only Switzerland fails to guarantee woman's salary following childbirth--even though it requires by law that women take eight weeks off after having baby; maternity benefits were approved in principle in 1945, but Swiss have three times voted down attempts to put policy into practice; opponents worry that money for new benefits would come from state coffers (M)
docs.snippet: The Swiss will decide on Sunday whether to provide new mothers with the kind of salary protections that every other Western European country affords women after they give birth.    While such benefits are tenuous in the United States, they are common...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Francis Fukuyama omits a key point in his attempt to prove that the pill will unleash behaviors bound to destroy the Japanese family (Op-Ed, June 9). Japanese women are already trying to control their fertility, but with limited success. Rates of unintended pregnancy and abortion have been high for decades, showing that the limited number of contraceptive methods available are insufficient. Eighty-nine percent of married women say they want to postpone their next pregnancy or stop childbearing.

headline.main: Don't Blame Birth Control for Society's Ills

docs.abstract: Letter from Alexander C Sanger of Margaret Sanger Center International replies to Francis Fukuyama's June 9 Op-Ed article, saying Japanese women are already trying to control fertility, but are having limited success without oral contraceptives
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Francis Fukuyama omits a key point in his attempt to prove that the pill will unleash behaviors bound to destroy the Japanese family (Op-Ed, June 9). Japanese women are already trying to control their fertility, but with limited...

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States has met only about 15 percent of its health goals for the year 2000, set 20 years ago, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today, but progress has been made on 44 percent. For about 20 percent of the objectives, the nation is getting less healthy and is moving away from the goals, Surgeon General David Satcher said at a news conference at Harvard Medical School in Boston.

headline.main: Nation Is Falling Short Of Health Goals for 2000

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Dept reports that United States has met only about 15 percent of its health goals for year 2000, set 20 years ago, but progress has been made on 44 percent; Surgeon Gen David Satcher and Health and Human Services Sec Donna Shalala comment on progress report; charts shows mixed results for nation's health in areas of infant mortality, school violence, asthma hospitalizations and influenza immunizations (M)
docs.snippet: The United States has met only about 15 percent of its health goals for the year 2000, set 20 years ago, the Department of Health and Human Services reported today, but progress has been made on 44 percent.    For about 20 percent of the objectives,...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 35 years after the birth control pill was introduced in the United States and other Western countries, an advisory council to Japan's Ministry of Health and Welfare finally decided in early June that it was safe enough for Japanese women to use. Japanese couples currently rely on condoms, the rhythm method and abortion (which is nonetheless frowned upon by both Buddhism and Shinto) to avoid unwanted pregnancies. Japanese feminists lobbied hard to have the pill approved, particularly after the impotence drug Viagra was quickly approved by the (presumably) aging men in Japan's health bureaucracy. Many people in the West see this as another example of Japan's quaint backwardness, like the persistence of keiretsu business networks in an age of high-tech, global capitalism.

headline.main: At Last, Japan Gets the Pill. Is This Good News?

docs.abstract: Francis Fukuyama Op-Ed article says Japanese Government's approval of birth-control pill may well damage the prized social stability of the nation; notes that in United States and other Western countries, introduction of pill was followed by explosion of illegitimacy, divorce and single-parent families (M)
docs.snippet: More than 35 years after the birth control pill was introduced in the United States and other Western countries, an advisory council to Japan's Ministry of Health and Welfare finally decided in early June that it was safe enough for Japanese women to...

docs.lead_paragraph: With a bit of fanfare but limited hard evidence, a Maryland pharmaceutical company has begun marketing a dietary supplement said to improve sperm quality to couples having trouble conceiving. Already, even while cautioning that research is still needed to verify the claims, some fertility specialists have begun recommending to patients that they try the product, Proxeed. In large part, they say, they are doing so because the active ingredients, long used for other purposes, appear to have no side-effects.

headline.main: In Search Of a Way To Bolster The Sperm

docs.abstract: Sigma-Tau Pharmaceuticals introduces Proxeed, dietary supplement it says improves sperm quality, and it is marketing it to couples having trouble conceiving; some fertility specialists are recommending it to patients, while cautioning that claim must still be verified by research; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With a bit of fanfare but limited hard evidence, a Maryland pharmaceutical company has begun marketing a dietary supplement said to improve sperm quality to couples having trouble conceiving.    Already, even while cautioning that research is still...

docs.lead_paragraph: It would seem easy to predict how Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, one of the nation's most prominent Republican moderates, would deal with a string of conservative proposals that may be headed her way in the next few months. Require parental consent for a teen-ager to get a tattoo or have an ear pierced? Mrs. Whitman previously vetoed a similar bill.

headline.main: For Whitman, Move to Right May Be Sole Way to Move Up

docs.abstract: New Jersey conservatives are making it abundantly clear to Gov Christine Todd Whitman, as she prepares for race next year for open US Senate seat, that she will have to yield ground on several issues if she hopes to hold on to their crucial support; Whitman won her two races for Governor by less than 1 percent of vote, making conservative support critical, especially because Senate race is in Presidential election year, when many traditionally Democratic urban voters are likely to go to polls; Whitman, whose standing among conservatives has weakened over years because of her moderate views on social issues, needs every vote she can get; photo (M)
